description: A Joliet father and son were pinched in connection with an early Sunday morning drive-by shooting following a chase on the city's East Side, police said. Officers responded to North Eastern Avenue between Benton and Webster streets shortly before 2 a.m. to investigate a report of shots fired, according to police. The fleeing SUV stopped as block or so away on...
text:
A Joliet father and son were pinched in connection with an early Sunday
morning drive-by shooting following a chase on the city's East Side, police
said.

Officers responded to North Eastern Avenue between Benton and Webster streets
shortly before 2 a.m. to investigate a report of shots fired, according to
police.

Officers determined the shooter was riding in a dark-colored SUV, police said,
and the gunman opened fire on a residence, hitting it numerous times.

No one was injured in the gun attack, police said, and the SUV fled the scene.

Officers spotted a dark-colored SUV a few blocks away near the intersection of
Collins and Jackson streets and tried to pull it over, police said, but
instead of stopping, the vehicle took off.

During the ensuing chase, the passenger, later identified as Juan Mendoza Jr.,
24, bailed out of the SUV and made a run for it, police said.

The law caught up with Mendoza on the porch of a Webster Street home where he
"refused to follow officers' commands to place his hands behind his back, but
was eventually placed into custody," police said.

"A discarded loaded firearm was recovered in close proximity to where" Mendoza
was arrested, according to police.

The fleeing SUV stopped as block or so away on Benton Street and the driver,
Juan Mendoza Sr., was arrested, police said.

Officers also found a bag of cocaine in the SUV, police said.

The father and son, who live in the same house on Massachusetts Avenue,
according to police, were booked into the Will County jail.

The elder Mendoza was arrested on probable cause of aggravated fleeing and
possession of a controlled substance, according to jail records.

The younger Mendoza was arrested on probable cause of possession of a weapon
by a felon, possession of a firearm by a gang member, resisting a police
officer, possession of ammunition without an owner's identification card,
possession of a firearm without an owner's identification card and aggravated
unlawful use of a weapon, jail records show.

title: Father-son drive-by shooting duo nabbed after gun attack: cops
html:
A Joliet father and son were pinched in connection with an early Sunday morning drive-by shooting following a chase on the city's East Side, police said.

Officers responded to North Eastern Avenue between Benton and Webster streets shortly before 2 a.m. to investigate a report of shots fired, according to police.

Officers determined the shooter was riding in a dark-colored SUV, police said, and the gunman opened fire on a residence, hitting it numerous times.

No one was injured in the gun attack, police said, and the SUV fled the scene.

Officers spotted a dark-colored SUV a few blocks away near the intersection of Collins and Jackson streets and tried to pull it over, police said, but instead of stopping, the vehicle took off.

During the ensuing chase, the passenger, later identified as Juan Mendoza Jr., 24, bailed out of the SUV and made a run for it, police said.

The law caught up with Mendoza on the porch of a Webster Street home where he "refused to follow officers' commands to place his hands behind his back, but was eventually placed into custody," police said.

"A discarded loaded firearm was recovered in close proximity to where" Mendoza was arrested, according to police.

The fleeing SUV stopped as block or so away on Benton Street and the driver, Juan Mendoza Sr., was arrested, police said.

Officers also found a bag of cocaine in the SUV, police said.

The father and son, who live in the same house on Massachusetts Avenue, according to police, were booked into the Will County jail.

The elder Mendoza was arrested on probable cause of aggravated fleeing and possession of a controlled substance, according to jail records.

The younger Mendoza was arrested on probable cause of possession of a weapon by a felon, possession of a firearm by a gang member, resisting a police officer, possession of ammunition without an owner's identification card, possession of a firearm without an owner's identification card and aggravated unlawful use of a weapon, jail records show.
